values.description:
ported Mesh and SubMesh classes from gazebo.

changes:

- separated them into two files

- pimpl'ized

- used c++11 where possible

- updated doxygen

- removed `Get` from function names. Note that this doesn't work in all cases. Some cause conflict between class names. e.g. `Mesh::GetSkeleton` has to be renamed to `Mesh::MeshSkeleton` because `Mesh::Skeleton` refuses to compile

- added unit tests

- kept original test in `test/integration/mesh.cc`. It needs other classes that are not ported yet so won't compile and so not added to cmake
values.title: Add Mesh and SubMesh classes

summary.raw:
ported Mesh and SubMesh classes from gazebo.

changes:

- separated them into two files

- pimpl'ized

- used c++11 where possible

- updated doxygen

- removed `Get` from function names. Note that this doesn't work in all cases. Some cause conflict between class names. e.g. `Mesh::GetSkeleton` has to be renamed to `Mesh::MeshSkeleton` because `Mesh::Skeleton` refuses to compile

- added unit tests

- kept original test in `test/integration/mesh.cc`. It needs other classes that are not ported yet so won't compile and so not added to cmake
summary.html:
ported Mesh and SubMesh classes from gazebo.

changes:

  • separated them into two files

  • pimpl'ized

  • used c++11 where possible

  • updated doxygen

  • removed Get from function names. Note that this doesn't work in all cases. Some cause conflict between class names. e.g. Mesh::GetSkeleton has to be renamed to Mesh::MeshSkeleton because Mesh::Skeleton refuses to compile

  • added unit tests

  • kept original test in test/integration/mesh.cc. It needs other classes that are not ported yet so won't compile and so not added to cmake

values.description:
This is the first part of windows patches:

* Added configure.bat file
* Update compiler detection
* Do not include visibility in the function definition
* Added DLL definitions to add_library
* Proper preprocessor keyword
* Use ignition constant
* Remove unneeded time headers
* Import check_gcc_visibily

Still some work to be done, but we have [advanced in the compilation](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/12/console).
values.title: Port to Windows: part I

summary.raw:

* Added configure.bat file
* Update compiler detection
* Do not include visibility in the function definition
* Added DLL definitions to add_library
* Proper preprocessor keyword

Still some work to be done, but we have [advanced in the compilation](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/12/console).

values.title: Adds PluginLoader

summary.html:
This is the plugin loader from the ecs prototype. It can load any class as a plugin.

Here's how to use it to load a plugin

// Include this header to manage plugin paths
#include <ignition/common/SystemPaths.hh>
// Include this header to load plugins
#include <ignition/common/PluginLoader.hh>

// ...

ignition::common::SystemPaths sp;
ignition::common::PluginLoader pm;

// Set environment variable with paths. Default IGN_PLUGIN_PATH
sp->SetPluginPathEnv("GAZEBO_PLUGIN_PATH");
// Get the path to the library
std::string pathToLib = sp->FindSharedLibrary("MySharedLibraryName");

// Loads library, returns name of plugin if library exists and has one
std::string pluginName = pm.LoadLibrary(pathToLib)

// Want to show user a gui with available plugins? That info is available
std::cout << pm.PrettyStr();
/* Example output:
PluginLoader State
        Known Interfaces: 1
                ::test::util::DummyPluginBase
        Known Plugins: 1
                ::test::util::DummyPlugin (::test::util::DummyPluginBase)
*/

// Load a plugin, expecting it to inherit from a base class
// there are no restrictions on what that base class is!
std::unique_ptr<any_namespace::AnyBaseClass> pluginInst;
pluginInst = pm.Instantiate<any_namespace::AnyBaseClass>("::my_namespace::MyPlugin");

Here's how to create a plugin

// Need a base class, can be anything
class AnyBaseClass
{
   // ...
};

// ...
// In a shared library
// ...
// MyPlugin.hh

// MUST inherit from the base class
class MyPlugin : public ::any_namespace::AnyBaseClass
{
  // ...
};

// ...
// MyPlugin.cpp
// ...

// Need this header for a macro
#include <ignition/common/PluginMacros.hh>

IGN_COMMON_REGISTER_SINGLE_PLUGIN(::my_namespace::MyPlugin, ::any_namespace::AnyBaseClass);

values.description:
Let downstream users add a custom prefix to the console messages.

The motivation is that once we have many different ignition libraries using the same logging style, it might be difficult to tell where the error is coming from.

For example, at the moment, Gazebo and SDF use slightly different console styles and even so it takes a trained eye to tell that the errors above came from SDF while the ones below came from Gazebo:

![warn.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9opaEB/images/2161259596-warn.png)

I'm integrating Ignition Common's logger into Ignition GUI and I'm planning on adopting this style:

![igngui.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/9opaEB/images/3544438375-igngui.png)
values.title: Custom prefix for console logging

The motivation is that once we have many different ignition libraries using the same logging style, it might be difficult to tell where the error is coming from.

For example, at the moment, Gazebo and SDF use slightly different console styles and even so it takes a trained eye to tell that the errors above came from SDF while the ones below came from Gazebo:

I'm integrating Ignition Common's logger into Ignition GUI and I'm planning on adopting this style:

values.description:
Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library 

The use of `/MDd` for the Debug compilation type and `/MD` for all the other is already ensured by the `Windows-MSVC` CMake Platform [2] file in `NMake Makefiles`, `ninja` and `Visual Studio` generators, 
so those lines should not be necessary. 

Furthermore, on Multi Config CMake Generators such as Visual Studio, the `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` variables does not contain the actual configuration with which the code is compiled, that is instead specified by the user at compile time rather than configuration time. This mean that 
the `/MD` flag (linking with the Non-Debug CRT Dynamic Library) is passed even to Debug builds, and this causes linking error with third-party debug dependencies in gazebo . See [2] for a proper way of manipulating config-specific compilation flags for both Single Config and Multiple Config generators. 

[1] https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/6dc7262bf77f551a7f3c36d7ca3023c63ef20af8/Modules/Platform/Windows-MSVC.cmake#L292


[2] https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#How_can_I_build_my_MSVC_application_with_a_static_runtime.3F
values.title: Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library

summary.raw:
Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library 

The use of `/MDd` for the Debug compilation type and `/MD` for all the other is already ensured by the `Windows-MSVC` CMake Platform [2] file in `NMake Makefiles`, `ninja` and `Visual Studio` generators, 
so those lines should not be necessary. 

Furthermore, on Multi Config CMake Generators such as Visual Studio, the `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` variables does not contain the actual configuration with which the code is compiled, that is instead specified by the user at compile time rather than configuration time. This mean that 
the `/MD` flag (linking with the Non-Debug CRT Dynamic Library) is passed even to Debug builds, and this causes linking error with third-party debug dependencies in gazebo . See [2] for a proper way of manipulating config-specific compilation flags for both Single Config and Multiple Config generators. 

[1] https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/6dc7262bf77f551a7f3c36d7ca3023c63ef20af8/Modules/Platform/Windows-MSVC.cmake#L292


[2] https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#How_can_I_build_my_MSVC_application_with_a_static_runtime.3F
summary.html:
Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library

The use of /MDd for the Debug compilation type and /MD for all the other is already ensured by the Windows-MSVC CMake Platform [2] file in NMake Makefiles, ninja and Visual Studio generators, so those lines should not be necessary.

Furthermore, on Multi Config CMake Generators such as Visual Studio, the CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE variables does not contain the actual configuration with which the code is compiled, that is instead specified by the user at compile time rather than configuration time. This mean that the /MD flag (linking with the Non-Debug CRT Dynamic Library) is passed even to Debug builds, and this causes linking error with third-party debug dependencies in gazebo . See [2] for a proper way of manipulating config-specific compilation flags for both Single Config and Multiple Config generators.

[1] https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/6dc7262bf77f551a7f3c36d7ca3023c63ef20af8/Modules/Platform/Windows-MSVC.cmake#L292

[2] https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#How_can_I_build_my_MSVC_application_with_a_static_runtime.3F

values.description:
In case anyone was wondering, I've isolated the classes which currently are not building on our Windows CI. This branch builds:

https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/110/

Most of the problems are related to missing dependencies, but there are a couple of header-related issues too.
values.title: Isolate classes which are failing on our Jenkins Windows job

https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/110/

Most of the problems are related to missing dependencies, but there are a couple of header-related issues too.
summary.html:
In case anyone was wondering, I've isolated the classes which currently are not building on our Windows CI. This branch builds:

https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/110/

Most of the problems are related to missing dependencies, but there are a couple of header-related issues too.

values.description:
A couple of fixed problems:

 * It was hardcoded to use the system version only in Windows. I've change it to honor the user defined variable in other platforms.

 * The headers were using '<ignition/tinyxml2>' what made impossible to use the system version of tinyxml. I've relocated the embedded version to make it compatible with both.
values.title: Fix the build when using the tinyxml2 system

summary.raw:
A couple of fixed problems:

 * It was hardcoded to use the system version only in Windows. I've change it to honor the user defined variable in other platforms.

 * The headers were using '<ignition/tinyxml2>' what made impossible to use the system version of tinyxml. I've relocated the embedded version to make it compatible with both.
summary.html:
A couple of fixed problems:

  • It was hardcoded to use the system version only in Windows. I've change it to honor the user defined variable in other platforms.

  • The headers were using '<ignition/tinyxml2>' what made impossible to use the system version of tinyxml. I've relocated the embedded version to make it compatible with both.

values.description: This adds a method to SystemPaths to look for a file within a list of searh paths. The use case is finding world files in the install directory. The existing `FindFile` method is not sufficient because it only searches the current working directory.
values.title: Added SystemPaths::FindFile overload that accepts a list of search paths

summary.raw: This adds a method to SystemPaths to look for a file within a list of searh paths. The use case is finding world files in the install directory. The existing `FindFile` method is not sufficient because it only searches the current working directory.
summary.html: This adds a method to SystemPaths to look for a file within a list of searh paths. The use case is finding world files in the install directory. The existing FindFile method is not sufficient because it only searches the current working directory.

values.description: `WorkerPool` manages a bunch of worker threads. Each thread gets a job from a queue in the pool and processes it in parallel. "Work" is a function that does something useful and returns in a finite amount of time.
values.title: Thread/Worker pool

summary.raw: `WorkerPool` manages a bunch of worker threads. Each thread gets a job from a queue in the pool and processes it in parallel. "Work" is a function that does something useful and returns in a finite amount of time.
summary.html: WorkerPool manages a bunch of worker threads. Each thread gets a job from a queue in the pool and processes it in parallel. "Work" is a function that does something useful and returns in a finite amount of time.

values.description:
Currently ignition-comon pull request show build failures because jenkins sees the static assertion tests (which pass if they don't compile) as build failures. This pull request adds a test runner to the static assertion tests to censor output to prevent Jenkins from marking the whole build as a failure. The static_assert tests have been made UNIX only because they rely on a bash script.

It also disables the two FQN name tests since they don't work anyways.
values.title: Fix jenkins seeing static_assertion tests as build failures

summary.raw:
Currently ignition-comon pull request show build failures because jenkins sees the static assertion tests (which pass if they don't compile) as build failures. This pull request adds a test runner to the static assertion tests to censor output to prevent Jenkins from marking the whole build as a failure. The static_assert tests have been made UNIX only because they rely on a bash script.

It also disables the two FQN name tests since they don't work anyways.
summary.html:
Currently ignition-comon pull request show build failures because jenkins sees the static assertion tests (which pass if they don't compile) as build failures. This pull request adds a test runner to the static assertion tests to censor output to prevent Jenkins from marking the whole build as a failure. The static_assert tests have been made UNIX only because they rely on a bash script.

It also disables the two FQN name tests since they don't work anyways.

values.description: This eliminates a c-linkage warning on OSX. The issue is the macro creates a function with `extern "C"` that returns a struct `PluginInfo` that isn't a pure C struct. The plugin API version has been bumped and the `IGNCOMMONSinglePluginInfo()` prototype has been changed to use pure C types `(void *, size_t)` which it casts to a `PluginInfo*` and populates.
values.title: Fixed c-linkage warning from PluginLoader on OSX

summary.raw: This eliminates a c-linkage warning on OSX. The issue is the macro creates a function with `extern "C"` that returns a struct `PluginInfo` that isn't a pure C struct. The plugin API version has been bumped and the `IGNCOMMONSinglePluginInfo()` prototype has been changed to use pure C types `(void *, size_t)` which it casts to a `PluginInfo*` and populates.
summary.html: This eliminates a c-linkage warning on OSX. The issue is the macro creates a function with extern "C" that returns a struct PluginInfo that isn't a pure C struct. The plugin API version has been bumped and the IGNCOMMONSinglePluginInfo() prototype has been changed to use pure C types (void *, size_t) which it casts to a PluginInfo* and populates.

values.description: This fixes a test failure of the plugin loader on OSX. If the base class symbol is not marked as visible, `typeid()` may return different `std::type_info` for the type in the shared library versus the type in the executable loading the library. This caused a lookup in `PluginLoader::Instantiate` to fail to find the plugin to be instantiated.
values.title: Fix PluginLoader.LoadExistingLibrary test failure on OSX

summary.raw: This fixes a test failure of the plugin loader on OSX. If the base class symbol is not marked as visible, `typeid()` may return different `std::type_info` for the type in the shared library versus the type in the executable loading the library. This caused a lookup in `PluginLoader::Instantiate` to fail to find the plugin to be instantiated.
summary.html: This fixes a test failure of the plugin loader on OSX. If the base class symbol is not marked as visible, typeid() may return different std::type_info for the type in the shared library versus the type in the executable loading the library. This caused a lookup in PluginLoader::Instantiate to fail to find the plugin to be instantiated.

values.description: `dlerror()` returns a human readable string describing the last error encountered. This pull request logs it.
values.title: Log a human readable error when a plugin library cannot be dynamically loaded

values.title: More readable errors for plugin loader

values.description:
This brings the port of boost filesystem @clalancette added to sdformat into ignition common.

There were some equivalent functions in both: `exists`, `isDirectory`, `append/joinPaths`. The ones already in `ignition-common` were kept and the ones from the port were removed. All filesystem function declarations in `Util.hh` were moved to `Filesystem.hh`, and an include of `Filesystem.hh` was added to `Util.hh` so existing code doesn't break.

The BOOST licensed implementations are in ~~Filesystem.cc~~ `FilesystemBoost.cc`, and the Apache 2.0 licensed implementations are in ~~FilesystemOSRF.cc~~ `Filesystem.cc`. I moved filesystem function implementations from `Util.cc` into ~~FilesystemOSRF.cc~~ `Filesystem.cc`.  Filesystem tests were moved from `Util_TEST.cc` to `Filesystem_TEST.cc`.

Some function names in the port were changed to match the style guide, but anything within ~~Filesystem.cc~~ `FilesystemBoost.cc` was left alone.
values.title: Port SDF Filesystem to Ignition Common

summary.raw:
This brings the port of boost filesystem @clalancette added to sdformat into ignition common.

There were some equivalent functions in both: `exists`, `isDirectory`, `append/joinPaths`. The ones already in `ignition-common` were kept and the ones from the port were removed. All filesystem function declarations in `Util.hh` were moved to `Filesystem.hh`, and an include of `Filesystem.hh` was added to `Util.hh` so existing code doesn't break.

The BOOST licensed implementations are in ~~Filesystem.cc~~ `FilesystemBoost.cc`, and the Apache 2.0 licensed implementations are in ~~FilesystemOSRF.cc~~ `Filesystem.cc`. I moved filesystem function implementations from `Util.cc` into ~~FilesystemOSRF.cc~~ `Filesystem.cc`.  Filesystem tests were moved from `Util_TEST.cc` to `Filesystem_TEST.cc`.

Some function names in the port were changed to match the style guide, but anything within ~~Filesystem.cc~~ `FilesystemBoost.cc` was left alone.
summary.html:
This brings the port of boost filesystem @clalancette added to sdformat into ignition common.

There were some equivalent functions in both: exists, isDirectory, append/joinPaths. The ones already in ignition-common were kept and the ones from the port were removed. All filesystem function declarations in Util.hh were moved to Filesystem.hh, and an include of Filesystem.hh was added to Util.hh so existing code doesn't break.

The BOOST licensed implementations are in Filesystem.cc FilesystemBoost.cc, and the Apache 2.0 licensed implementations are in FilesystemOSRF.cc Filesystem.cc. I moved filesystem function implementations from Util.cc into FilesystemOSRF.cc Filesystem.cc. Filesystem tests were moved from Util_TEST.cc to Filesystem_TEST.cc.

Some function names in the port were changed to match the style guide, but anything within Filesystem.cc FilesystemBoost.cc was left alone.
